details.title: Optimal test planning for the fatigue-limit model when the fatigue-limit distribution is known

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math., Washington State Univ., Pullman, WA, USA

p: Francis G. Pascual received his Ph.D. (1997) from the Department of Statistics at Iowa State University in Ames. He has a joint appointment in the Program of Statistics and the Department of Mathematics at Washington State University in Pullman, Washington.

authors.name: F.G. Pascual

details.abstract: This article discusses tools for planning life tests under the random fatigue-limit model, when the form of the fatigue-limit distribution is completely specified. Expressions for the Fisher information matrix elements are provided. Test-plan objectives, such as minimum variance of quantile or parameter estimator, can be written in terms of these expressions. Under Type I censoring, all experimental conditions can be described by a standardized slope parameter & a standardized log(censoring time). This article provides equivalence theorems, which can be used to check the optimality of test plans which often have two levels. The best three-level standard test plans are not optimal, but, in general, involve fewer extrapolations to low stresses than the optimal plans. Test plans for a titanium-alloy fatigue test are presented to illustrate the methods.

context.text: The 4:2:1 allocation plan discussed in [10] is a more recent variation on the compromise plan where levels are equally spaced with 4/7, 2/7, & 1/7 of units allocated at the lowest, middle, & highest levels, respectively.

These plans will be evaluated in terms of the amount of extrapolation to stress levels of interest, estimation efficiency, robustness to model misspecification, and expected numbers of failures as was done here, and in [10].

references.text: W. Q. Meeker, G. J. Hahn, How to Plan an Accelerated Life Test&#821Some Practical Guidelines, vol. 10, ASQC Basic References in Quality Control, Statistical Techniques.

references.title: Estimating fatigue curves with the random fatigue-limit model (with discussion)

context.text: The random fatigue-limit (RFL) model, discussed in [11], describes how fatigue life is related to the applied load when fatigue limits vary from one test unit to another.
In [11], the RFL model suggested that the heteroscedasticity, often observed in fatigue life with respect to applied load, could be explained in part by the random nature of the fatigue limit.

The marginal probability density function (pdf) of \$W\$ under the random fatigue-limit (RFL) model in [11] is given by  where \$\phi _{W\vert V}\$ & \$\phi _{V}\$ denote the appropriate standard probability density functions [smallest extreme value (sev) or \$s\$-normal], and \$W\vert V\$ pertains to the conditional distribution of \$W\$ given the log(fatigue limit) \$V\$.
The objective of this article is to present the theory & underlying tools needed to develop test plans under the random fatigue-limit model in [11].

references.text: F. G. Pascual, W. Q. Meeker, "Estimating fatigue curves with the random fatigue-limit model (with discussion)", Technometrics, vol. 41, pp. 277-290.

references.title: Statistical Analysis of Fatigue Data

context.text: Planning values for \$\xi _{H}\$, \$\zeta\$, and \$\beta _{1}^{\ast }\$ are obtained from fitting the RFL model to a fatigue dataset of 96 Type I censored observations given in [12].

references.text: C. L. Shen, Statistical Analysis of Fatigue Data.

context.text: Estimates of fatigue limits, such as those given in [13] for different metals in reversed bending tests can be also used as inputs to obtain values for the mean or median fatigue limit.

references.text: E. A. Avallone, T. Baumeister III, "5" in Mechanical Properties of Materials in Marks' Standard Handbook for Mechanical Engineers, pp. 2-15, McGraw-Hill.
